text: I'm John Harwood with the new york times
in CNBC we're joined here at the
democratic convention at the pepsi
center in denver by chris van hollen the
chair of the Democratic Congressional
Campaign Committee and congressman let
me ask you a lot of attention to Joe
Biden selection is running mate over the
last couple of days but it's not clear
how much running mates effect even the a
presidential ticket itself does it have
any effect on the competitive races you
have in for Congress it does I think
that his working-class background and
the fact that he's been a great ally of
the policemen the firefighters working
men and women is going to be a great
asset in places like Ohio Pennsylvania
of course where he grew up in Scranton
Michigan a lot of other places where I
think his story will really connect and
will help boost our congressional
candidates now Barack Obama has found
himself in a much tighter race with John
McCain over the last few weeks and
earlier points in the cycle it looked
like in some of your competitive races
especially in the West places like here
in Colorado Nevada New Mexico that
Barack Obama was going to provide a lift
for your candidates and everybody was
welcoming that now he's got a real
dogfight in Ohio Michigan Pennsylvania
those states how are your candidates for
Congress feeling about Barack Obama as
the head of the Democratic ticket this
is a two-way street I think there are
lots of congressional races where Barack
Obama is going to provide a lift to our
candidates in Ohio the chabot seed is
one where we have a terrific candidate
Steve driehaus I in other candidates in
other areas i think some of our
candidates are going to help get out the
vote for barack obama in ohio you've got
John go cherry as a good example so
there's one state where one part of the
state Barack Obama's that they live to
our candidates in other places we think
our candidates and their field
operations will be a lift to the Obama
ticket now you have some candidates in
competitive races in the south other
places that are culturally conservative
how much resistance do you think or how
much complication it poses for your
candidates that you have a democratic
ticket headed by the first
african-american nominee well I think if
you look at our special elections that
you you could
that because in those elections the
Republicans tried to run against our
candidate by using Barack Obama and
Nancy Pelosi and it totally backfired
because people really are looking to
answers for the economic squeeze that
are they're feeling and they're not
going to get distracted by some of these
tactics that we've seen in the past I
think those are the best examples in
Mississippi in Louisiana we picked up
seats in the special election the George
Bush it carried by 61 percent of the
vote Mississippi fifty-nine percent of
the vote in Louisiana and again they
tried to use this tactic they ran ads
using Barack Obama against our
candidates and it just didn't work in
fact Republicans sent Dick Cheney down
and the day after that Mississippi
people came out overwhelmingly supported
our Canada one of the things that we've
seen in this very cluttered media
environment so much attention to
politics harder and harder for
candidates to get bounces out of their
convention John Kerry didn't get much of
if any of one out of two thousand four
what do you hope as a democratic leader
for the top of the ticket and for your
candidates to accomplish in these four
days in Denver our challenge is to draw
the clear contrast between what the
obama-biden ticket stands for and what a
McCain presidency that means go on the
attack again stomach you know it means
laying out the clear contrast on the
policy issues if you look at the economy
and you look at foreign policy what John
McCain represents is more the same in
fact on the economy this is george bush
on steroids you know if you like the
bush administration's economic policy
you're going to love john mccain whereas
obama has got a plan in terms of middle
class tax relief he's got a health care
plan that's going to help relieve that
middle class suites and so our challenge
is to tell the story of what differences
there are between these two individuals
not just in terms of their personalities
but more importantly for the American
people their policies congressman Chris
Van Hollen thanks so much for joining us
good to be with you I'm John Harwood
chief Washington correspondent for CNBC
